misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a physics average-acceleration calculator that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles and prints the average acceleration, instead of reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t, computes (v1 - v0) / t, and print the average acceleration, and that will answer this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read exactly 5 integers from the user, identify which of those values are even (using a condition like n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of those even values, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Only 3 values are read from input (v0, v1, t) instead of 5.
The core computation is averageAcceleration = (v1 - v0) / t rather than summing input values.
The output message is 'The average acceleration is ...' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: ...'.
No loop is used to process 5 inputs and no accumulator is used to sum even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have reused or focused on a different textbook example (average acceleration) and did not align their solution with the specific requirement to sum even numbers from 5 integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Identify the required inputs (5 integers), the required processing (loop over 5 numbers, check evenness with n % 2 == 0, accumulate sum), and the required output format, then design your code around those steps.
related_concepts: Basic program design from a prompt
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program (variable names, prompt text, formula, and output message) matches a standard average-acceleration example and does not implement any part of the requested 'sum of 5 even numbers' behavior.

evidence.note: Code reads three doubles v0, v1, t and computes average acceleration instead of reading five integers and preparing to sum even numbers.
Both branches print an average acceleration message; there is no mention of summing even numbers or printing 'Sum of even numbers: ...'.

misconceptions.name: Using integer division instead of modulus to test evenness / misunderstanding integer division
misconceptions.description: The student uses the condition (num / 2 == 0) with an int cast from t, rather than using num % 2 == 0 to test whether a number is even, indicating confusion about how to check evenness and how integer division behaves.
misconceptions.student_belief: To check if a value is even, I can divide it by 2 and compare the result to 0 (num / 2 == 0).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To check if an integer n is even, you must test whether the remainder when dividing by 2 is zero, using n % 2 == 0. Integer division n / 2 gives the quotient, not the remainder, and will be 1 for n = 2, 2 for n = 4, etc.
symptoms: Casting a double t to an int and then using num / 2 == 0 as a boolean condition.
No use of the modulus operator (%) anywhere to test evenness.
The condition num / 2 == 0 is false for most positive integers except 0 and 1, so it cannot correctly identify even numbers.
The condition appears where an evenness test would belong according to the rubric, but uses division instead.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between quotient and remainder in division, and not understanding how integer division truncates results, combined with not knowing that modulus (%) is the appropriate operator for even/odd checks.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review how integer division and the modulus operator work in Java. Try small examples (e.g., 0, 1, 2, 3, 4) and print both n / 2 and n % 2 to see the difference. Then replace the condition with num % 2 == 0 when checking for even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The use of num / 2 == 0 in an if condition, in a problem about even numbers (per rubric), strongly suggests confusion about how to test evenness and about integer division, although the overall program is for a different task.

evidence.note: t is cast to an int and num / 2 == 0 is used as the if condition, where an evenness test using % would be expected.

misconceptions.name: Failed to address the assigned problem (Misunderstanding Requirements)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate average acceleration using three double inputs (v0, v1, t), rather than the required program to read five integers and sum the even ones. This represents a complete failure to meet the assignment requirements, possibly due to copy-pasting code from another problem or misreading the prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to calculate and display average acceleration, possibly filtering the output based on a property of the time variable 't'.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading 5 integers and calculating the sum of only the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Program input logic reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers.
Program calculates acceleration instead of an even sum.
Variable names (v0, v1, t, avgAcceleration) are unrelated to the problem.
Output messages reference 'average acceleration'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation or complete misunderstanding of the problem's requirements, resulting in a solution for an entirely different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always read the prompt carefully. Ensure your program's logic, variable names, and expected inputs/outputs match all requirements specified in the assignment.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code's entire structure and functionality is clearly designed for a different physics problem, not the summing of even numbers.

evidence.note: The class name suggests a different problem related to calculating acceleration, not summing even numbers.
Reads three doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers.
Calculates average acceleration, not sum of evens.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect check for even numbers using division
misconceptions.description: The student attempts a conditional check that seems related to even/odd, but uses integer division (`num / 2 == 0`) which only evaluates as true when `num` is 0 or 1 due to integer division truncation (or just 0 if `num` is positive). This is an incorrect method for checking parity compared to the modulus operator (`%`).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that if the result of dividing a number by 2 is 0 (using integer division), the number must be even.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To check if an integer `n` is even, one must use the modulus operator: `n % 2 == 0`. Integer division does not yield the remainder.
symptoms: The conditional check `if (num / 2 == 0)` will only be true if `num` is 0, regardless of whether it's an even number or not (assuming non-negative inputs).
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of understanding of the behavior of integer division in conditional checks for parity, or confusion between integer division and the modulus operator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use the modulus operator (`%`) to find the remainder of a division. An integer `n` is even if `n % 2` is 0.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The expression `num / 2 == 0` is clearly present, coupled with a redundant `if/else` block, indicating a misunderstanding of how to check for evenness.

evidence.note: Uses integer division (num / 2 == 0) to check for a condition, instead of the modulus operator (num % 2 == 0).

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have solved a completely different problem. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers, the student wrote code to calculate average acceleration from physics (reading v0, v1, and t). This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of what the assignment is asking for.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to calculate average acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t, rather than reading 5 integers and summing the even ones.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, identifying which ones are even (divisible by 2), and printing the sum of only those even numbers. For the sample input '3 8 2 7 4', the even numbers are 8, 2, and 4, which sum to 14.
symptoms: Code reads 3 values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
Prompts user for physics variables instead of integers
Performs acceleration calculation instead of even number filtering
No loop structure to process 5 inputs
No modulo operator (%) to check for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either solved the wrong problem, copied code from a different assignment, or fundamentally misread the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. You need to: (1) Read 5 integers in a loop, (2) Check if each is even using (number % 2 == 0), (3) Add even numbers to a running sum, (4) Print the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves an entirely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) that is completely unrelated to the stated assignment (sum of even numbers). This is not a minor logic error but a fundamental misalignment with the task.

evidence.note: The code prompts for physics variables (v0, v1, t) instead of reading 5 integers as required by the assignment.
The code calculates average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers. There is no loop to process 5 integers and no modulo check for even numbers.

The conditional logic does not match the problem requirements. It prints acceleration in both branches and uses integer division (num / 2) rather than the modulo operator needed to check for even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Integer Division Instead of Modulo for Even/Odd Check
misconceptions.description: Even though the student is solving the wrong problem, there is also a technical misconception evident in line 15: using integer division (num / 2 == 0) instead of the modulo operator (num % 2 == 0) to check if a number is even. Integer division will never equal 0 for any positive number when divided by 2.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that dividing a number by 2 using integer division and checking if the result equals 0 will determine if the number is even.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To check if a number is even, use the modulo operator: num % 2 == 0. The modulo operator returns the remainder of division. Even numbers have a remainder of 0 when divided by 2. Integer division (num / 2) truncates the decimal part but does not give the remainder, so it cannot be used to check evenness.
symptoms: Condition 'num / 2 == 0' will never be true for positive integers
The logic will not correctly identify even numbers
Misunderstanding of the difference between / (division) and % (modulo)
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between the division operator (/) which performs division and returns a quotient, and the modulo operator (%) which returns the remainder. The student may not understand what modulo is or its purpose.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace 'num / 2 == 0' with 'num % 2 == 0'. The % operator returns the remainder. For even numbers, the remainder when divided by 2 is always 0.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence. The code clearly uses integer division (/) instead of modulo (%) to check for even numbers. This is a distinct misconception about which operator to use for this purpose, separate from the overall problem misunderstanding.

evidence.note: Uses integer division (num / 2) instead of modulo (num % 2) to check for even numbers. This condition will never be true for positive integers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (solving a different problem)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones, indicating a misunderstanding or disregard of the actual problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes average acceleration for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read exactly 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even, and print the sum of those even numbers. It should not compute physics formulas or use v0, v1, and t.
symptoms: Prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers.
Program reads only three values, all doubles.
Program computes `(v1 - v0) / t` instead of summing even numbers.
No loop or accumulator for summing even integers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different exercises or reusing code from a physics-related example without adapting it to this problem’s requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and the sample run carefully before writing code. Write down the required inputs, the exact processing steps (loop, condition), and the required output format, and then implement those steps directly.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (prompt, variable names, formula, output) is focused on acceleration and none of it addresses reading 5 integers or summing even numbers.

evidence.note: Code clearly implements an average acceleration calculation using v0, v1, and t, not reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Using integer division instead of modulus to test for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student attempts to use `num / 2 == 0` (with integer division) as a condition instead of the correct `num % 2 == 0`, indicating a misunderstanding of how to check for evenness and how integer division works.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can test whether a number is even by dividing it by 2 and checking if the result equals 0.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To test if an integer is even, you should use the modulus operator: `n % 2 == 0`. Integer division `n / 2` gives the quotient, not the remainder, so it is not suitable for checking evenness.
symptoms: Condition uses `num / 2 == 0` instead of `num % 2 == 0`.
Casting from double to int and using integer division in an if-condition unrelated to summing even numbers.
The if-condition will only be true for a very limited set of values (e.g., -1, 0, 1), not all even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between division and remainder, and not understanding how integer division truncates results.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the difference between `/` and `%` for integers. Practice writing small snippets that print `n / 2` and `n % 2` for various n to see how they differ, and then use `n % 2 == 0` to detect even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses `num / 2 == 0` in an if-statement, which matches a common misconception about even-number checking and integer division.

evidence.note: Here the student uses integer division `num / 2 == 0` instead of the correct even check `num % 2 == 0`.

symptoms: Code attempts to read 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Variable names (v0, v1, t, avgAcceleration) are non-relevant to the task
Solution calculates acceleration, not the sum of even numbers

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Evenness Check using Integer Division
misconceptions.description: The student attempted a conditional check, but likely intended to use the modulo operator (`%`) to check for evenness. Instead, they used integer division (`/`), which yields incorrect results for evenness checks (e.g., 4 / 2 is 2, not 0). Additionally, this check is performed on a non-relevant variable `t` (time/denominator).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student might believe that checking whether integer division by 2 results in 0 is sufficient for checking evenness, or they confused the `/` operator with the `%` operator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To check if an integer `n` is even, use the modulo operator: `n % 2 == 0`.
symptoms: Use of integer division in a boolean condition for even/odd determination
The condition `num / 2 == 0` is only true for `num` values of 0 or 1, not all even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between integer division operator (`/`) and modulo operator (`%`) for parity checking.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Recall that the modulo operator (`%`) gives the remainder of a division, which is essential for determining if a number is perfectly divisible by 2.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structure `if (num / 2 == 0)` strongly suggests an incorrect attempt at a parity check (which is the core logic for the required task Q1, even though it's applied incorrectly in the submitted code).

evidence.note: Uses integer division 'num / 2' instead of modulo 'num % 2' for a parity check.

misconceptions.name: Confusion between integer division and modulo operator for even number checking
misconceptions.description: The student uses integer division (/) instead of the modulo operator (%) to test properties of numbers. The code `(int)t / 2 == 0` attempts to check something about the number t, but this does not correctly identify even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that dividing a number by 2 and checking if the result is 0 is a way to test number properties (possibly evenness).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To check if a number is even, use the modulo operator: `n % 2 == 0`. The modulo operator returns the remainder after division, which is 0 only for even numbers. Integer division (/) discards the remainder and is not suitable for this check.
symptoms: Conditional logic doesn't correctly identify even numbers
Uses division (/) instead of modulo (%)
Condition will only be true when t < 2 (since (int)t / 2 == 0)
misconceptions.root_cause: The student confuses integer division with modulo. Integer division gives the quotient (e.g., 5/2 = 2), while modulo gives the remainder (e.g., 5%2 = 1). The student may not understand the difference between these operators.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace `num / 2 == 0` with `num % 2 == 0` to correctly test if a number is even.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses division to check a property of a number in a conditional, which is inconsistent with even-number checking. However, low confidence that this is the intended logic since the entire problem is misunderstood.

evidence.note: Uses integer division (/) instead of modulo (%) to test a property. This will not correctly identify even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental problem misinterpretation — solving wrong assignment
misconceptions.description: The student has solved a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration from velocity and time) rather than the assigned task (sum of even numbers). This indicates a critical misunderstanding of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to calculate average acceleration (a = (v1 - v0) / t), not to find the sum of even numbers from 5 integer inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading 5 integers, filtering the even ones, summing them, and printing the result. This is an input/loop/conditional/accumulation task, not a physics calculation.
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Program calculates velocity/acceleration formula instead of filtering and summing
Program output is acceleration value, not sum of even numbers
No loop to process multiple inputs
No logic to check if numbers are even
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either did not read the problem statement carefully, or worked on the wrong assignment file. They appear to be solving a physics/mechanics problem instead of a programming logic problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is: (1) Read 5 integers, (2) For each, check if even using n % 2 == 0, (3) Add even numbers to a running sum, (4) Print the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code's purpose (acceleration calculation) is fundamentally different from the assigned task (sum of even numbers). This is 100% certain.

evidence.note: Student reads physics variables (initial velocity, final velocity, time) and calculates acceleration, not the assigned task of summing even numbers.
Output is acceleration, not the sum of even numbers as required.
